encodingDesc.p: This document is a simplified "true-to-text" XML version of The Spanish Curate based on Pennsylvania State University's annotated copy of the 1647 Beaumont & Fletcher first folio. Major textual elements and attributes have been captured based on how they appear in the folio. Whenever possible, editorial interventions have been minimalized or avoided entirely. This document is meant to serve as a pedagogical tool by which students of Early Modern literature can learn to construct edited XML versions of the play.

projectDesc.p: The Digital Beaumont & Fletcher (1647) is a collaborative editorial project aimed at making many of the rarely edited—and, as a result, rarely taught—plays in the “Beaumont & Fletcher” canon accessible to student readers and freely available online for classroom use. This project was inspired by the distinctive copy of Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont And Iohn Fletcher Gentlemen (1647) held by Penn State University's Eberly Family Special Collections Library. In addition to preserving evidence of ownership dating to as early as 1703, Penn State's copy of this printed play collection also includes three plays with handwritten marginalia, suggesting that the book might have been used to facilitate performance in the late seventeenth century. This project is also motivated by a desire to make the texts and other features of this book more widely known and readable. As a first step, the whole volume has now been fully digitized, thanks to the department of Preservation, Conservation, and Digitization at Penn State Libraries.

handNote.p: This edition of The Spanish Curate contains the marginal notes found in the Penn State Libraries' copy of the 1647 folio. These manuscript notes are particually attentive to the performance of the play, and prepare actors for entrances and emphasize stage directions throughout the text. These manuscript notes have been added to the text without modernization spelling of puncuation.

sp.l: To tell ye, (gentlemen,) we have a play;
A new one too, and that 'tis launched launched: both presenting a play and therefore launching it, but also the imagery of a boat today.
The name ye know, that's nothing to my story;
To tell ye, 'tis familiar, uoid of Glory;
Of state, of bitterness: of wit you'll say,
For that is now held wit, that tends that way,
Which we avoid. To tell ye too 'tis merry,
And meant to make ye pleasant, and not weary.
The stream stream: prevailing direction of opinion that guides ye, easy to attendattend: listen to:
To tell ye that 'tis good, is to no end,
If you believe not. Nay, to go thus far,
To swear it, if you swear against, is war;
To assure you anything, unless you see,
And so conceive conceive: understand, is vanity in me.
Therefore, I leave it to itself, and pray
Like a good bark bark: small ship, it may work out today,
And stem all doubts; 'twas built for such a proof proof: act of testing,
And we hope highly. If she lie aloof lie aloof: nautical term, to the windward side
For her own vantage vantage: profit, to give wind at will give wind at will: to avail oneself of (wind) for sailing ,
Why let her work, only be you still,
And sweet opinioned, and we are bound to say,
You are worthy judges, and you crown the play crown the play: confer the highest praise on.

lg.l: Oh, here they come,
I now may spare his character, but observe him.
He'll justify my report.
My good Ascanio
Repair repair: return to specific place or person more often to me. Above women,
Thou ever shalt be welcome.
My Lord, your favours
May quickly teach a raw untutoured untutored: uneducated youth
To be both rude and saucy saucy: rude or cheeky.
You cannot be
Too frequent where you are so desired.
And give me leave, (dear friend), to be your rival
In part of his affection. I will buy it
At any rate.
Stood I but now possessed
Of what my future hope presages presages: warnings or omens of future events to me,
I then would make it clear thou ha'dst a patron patron: server or protector
That would not say but do. Yet, as I am,
Be mine. I'll not receive thee as a servant,
But as my son, and, (though I want myself),
No page page: boy or servant attending in the court of Spain

Shall find a kinder master I'll not recieve thee...a kinder master: Jamie claims that he would not treat Ascanio as a servant, which would be expected given Ascanio's status as a page, but as a son. There is a certain level of privilage with Jamie's statement. In terms of Jamie's authority, he has the ability to treat those who work for him as he pleases. In terms of Ascanio's status, because he is well-behaved, likely due to a certain level of education, and because he counts on gentlemen as his friends, he will likely be treated differently than other people in a similar role as him..
I beseech you
That my refusal of so great an offer
May make no ill construction. 'Tis not pride,
(That common vice is far from my condition),
That makes you a denial to receive
A favour I should sue for, nor the fashion
Which the country follows; in which to be a servant
In those that groan beneath the heavy weight
Of poverty is held an argument
Of a base and abject abject: low repute; despicable mind. I wish my years
Were fit to do you a service in a nature
That might become a gentleman; (give me leave
To think myself one). My father served the King
As a captain in the field; and though his fortune
Returned him home a poor man, he was rich
In reputation, and wounds fairly taken.
Nor am I by his ill success deterred;
I rather feel a strong desire that sways me
To follow his profession. And if heaven
Hath marked me out to be a man, how proud,
In the service of my country, should I be,
To trail a pike under your brave command.
There, I would follow you as a guide to honour,
Though all the horrors of the war made up
To stop my passage.
Thou art a hopeful boy,
And it was bravely spoken. For this answer,
I love thee more than ever.
Pity such seeds Manuscript note: Henrique be ready
Of promising courage should not grow and prosper.
Whatever his reputed parents be,
He hath a mind that speaks him right and noble.
You make him blush. It needs not sweet Ascanio,
We may hear praises when they are deserved,
Or modesty unwounded. By my life
I would add something to the building up
So fair a mind, and if till you are fit
To bear arms in the field, you'll spend some years
In Salamanca Salamanca: Referring to la Universidad de Salamanca. It was founded in 1218 and is the oldest university in the Hispanic world., I'll supply your studies
With all conveniences.
Your goodness, (Signiors),
And charitable favours overwhelm me.
If I were of your blood, you could not be
More tender of me. What then can I pay,
(A poor boy and a stranger), but a heart
Bound to your service? With what willingness
I would receive, (good sir), your noble offer,
Heaven can bear witness for me. But alas,
Should I embrace the means to raise my fortunes,
I must destroy the lives of my poor parents
(To whom I owe my being). They in me
Place all their comforts, and (as if I were
The light of their dim eyes) are so indulgent
They cannot brook brook: endure or tolerate one short day's absence from me.
And (what will hardly win belief) though young,
I am their steward and their nurse. The bounties
Which others bestow on me serves to sustain 'em,
And to forsake them in their age, in me
Were more than murder.

When thou art dead,

Now they begin to burn

My life for Don Jamie.
